<color>.prose: Colors in CSS are represented by the <color> type:

<rgba()>.prose: Also, an rgba() legacy color syntax also exists, with an identical grammar and behavior to rgb().

<hex-color>.prose: The syntax of a <hex-color> is a <hash-token> token whose value consists of 3, 4, 6, or 8 hexadecimal digits. In other words, a hex color is written as a hash character, "#", followed by some number of digits 0-9 or letters a-f (the case of the letters doesnâ€™t matter - #00ff00 is identical to #00FF00).

<named-color>.prose: CSS defines a large set of named colors, so that common colors can be written and read more easily. A <named-color> is written as an <ident>, accepted anywhere a <color> is. As usual for CSS-defined <ident>s, all of these keywords are ASCII case-insensitive.

<system-color>.prose: However, in forced colors mode, most colors on the page are forced into a restricted, user-chosen palette. The <system-color> keywords expose these user-chosen colors so that the rest of the page can integrate with this restricted palette.

<hsla()>.prose: Also, an hsla() legacy color syntax also exists, with an identical grammar and behavior to hsl().
